s.text: After the election, Holbrooke wrote a memo to Warren Christopher and Anthony Lake advocating the strategy known as "lift and strike"--lifting the arms embargo that prevented the Muslims from defending themselves, and bombing the Bosnian Serbs.

After the election, Holbrooke wrote a memo to Warren Christopher and Anthony Lake advocating the strategy known as "lift and strike"--lifting the arms embargo that prevented the Muslims from defending themselves, and bombing the Bosnian Serbs.

After the election, Holbrooke wrote a memo to Warren Christopher and Anthony Lake advocating the strategy known as "lift and strike"--lifting the arms embargo that prevented the Muslims from defending themselves, and bombing the Bosnian Serbs.
As part of candidate Clinton's foreign policy brain trust, Holbrooke prodded him to take an interventionist stand, which Clinton did.

In the summer of 1992, Holbrooke went to Bosnia as a private citizen, with a refugee aid organization, and saw horrors such as Muslims being driven out of the town of Banja Luka, where their families had lived for four centuries.
A courtier worthy of Shakespeare, Holbrooke is legendary for his flattery and back stabbing, and even for buttering someone up and sticking the knife in at the same time.
A courtier worthy of Shakespeare, Holbrooke is legendary for his flattery and back stabbing, and even for buttering someone up and sticking the knife in at the same time.
A courtier worthy of Shakespeare, Holbrooke is legendary for his flattery and back stabbing, and even for buttering someone up and sticking the knife in at the same time.
This tragedy spurred him in his hazardous ricocheting between Belgrade, Zagreb, and Sarajevo and helped bring about better-late-than-never NATO airstrikes in 1995.
By the end of the book, I couldn't help liking and admiring Holbrooke--not despite his evident flaws but in a curious way because of them.
By the end of the book, I couldn't help liking and admiring Holbrooke--not despite his evident flaws but in a curious way because of them.
By the end of the book, I couldn't help liking and admiring Holbrooke--not despite his evident flaws but in a curious way because of them.
His name-dropping is out of control.

Those who tend to roll their eyes at the mention of Holbrooke's name will find much eye-rolling material in his book To End a War: From Sarajevo to Dayton and Beyond , which is about his role in negotiating a peace settlement in Bosnia.
